text: [yelling in russian]

FRED PLEITGEN: They were some
of the largest demonstrations
Russia has seen in years--
[yelling in russian]

--thousands coming out
across the country,

hundreds detained
in Moscow alone.

OLGA LOZINA: She's
traumatized mentally.

FRED PLEITGEN: One
of them, Olga Lozina,

this picture of her arrest
going viral on the web.

OLGA LOZINA: It was
like a nightmare.
I couldn't believe my eyes.
The police officer mentioned me.
And he grabbed me by the hands.

But two men held me and
pulled me back to the crowd.

I wasn't hurt, but
I was traumatized.
[yelling in russian]

FRED PLEITGEN: This video on
social media shows her arrest,

Olga Lozina tells
CNN, saying she

was at the scene with
her mother and sister,

both also taken into
custody by Russian police.

Olga Lozina says she supports
the anti-corruption agenda
of Alexei Navalny.

The organizer of the protests
was arrested himself.
OLGA LOZINA: I support him.

And I am totally on his
side because corruption--

we all know that
Russia is corrupted.

FRED PLEITGEN:
Russia's government

has criticized the
anti-corruption demonstrations

held this past weekend, even
claiming some of the protesters

were offered money
if they got arrested,
a claim the organizers deny.

SERGEY PRAVOV:
Nothing will change.

FRED PLEITGEN: Sergey Pravov was
also detained by authorities,

he says, for singing Russia's
national anthem at the protest.

SERGEY PRAVOV:
[speaking russian]

INTERPRETER: We started
singing the national anthem.
We sang two verses.

Just as we got to the
"free country" part,

we were taken by the police
and thrown in the bus.
[singing in russian]

FRED PLEITGEN: Video of
Sergey Pravov's arrest

has also surfaced
on social media.

He says he wanted to
go to the demonstration

to protest widespread corruption
and inequality in Russia.

SERGEY PRAVOV:
[speaking russian]

INTERPRETER: People are tired
that they've nothing to eat,
they've no place to live.

They're tired of living
below the poverty line

while the people they
pay to rule wisely
are swimming in gold.

SERGEY PRAVOV:
[speaking russian]
[yelling in russian]

FRED PLEITGEN: Many others
had the same message
for Russia's government.

But it's not clear whether
those in power were listening.

This week, authorities
have warned

they would take an
even harder line

against unauthorized
protests in the future.
Fred Pleitgen, CNN, Moscow.
